statement.text: The neck is divided into three anatomic zones (I, II, III) for penetrating trauma management, with Zone I (clavicle to cricoid) and Zone III (angle of mandible to skull base) traditionally requiring preoperative imaging due to difficult surgical access, while Zone II (cricoid to mandible angle) is readily accessible for direct surgical exploration.

explanation.intuition: The neck is divided into three horizontal zones like a traffic light. Zone II in the middle (green) is surgically accessible - you can directly explore injuries. Zones I (bottom, at chest entrance) and III (top, near skull base) are 'red' - they're hard to reach surgically, so you need to know exactly what's injured before operating.
explanation.key_insight: Modern management has shifted from mandatory exploration of Zone II injuries to selective management based on CT angiography for all zones in stable patients. CTA has revolutionized penetrating neck trauma management by identifying injuries precisely, reducing negative explorations, and enabling endovascular treatment options.
explanation.technical_details: Zone I (thoracic inlet to cricoid): contains subclavian and proximal common carotid arteries, vertebral artery origin, trachea, esophagus, lung apex, thoracic duct. Zone II (cricoid to angle of mandible): common carotid, internal/external carotid bifurcation, internal jugular vein, larynx, pharynx, esophagus. Zone III (mandible angle to skull base): distal internal carotid, vertebral artery, pharynx, spinal cord. Traditional management: Zone II - direct exploration if platysma violated; Zones I/III - angiography first. Modern management: CTA for all zones in stable patients, guiding selective operative/endovascular intervention. Hard signs (active bleeding, expanding hematoma, stroke, air bubbling, massive hemoptysis) mandate immediate exploration regardless of zone.

Zone_I.access: Difficult - may require sternotomy, thoracotomy, or clavicular resection

Zone_II.boundaries: Cricoid cartilage to angle of mandible
Zone_II.access: Directly accessible via anterior cervical incision
Zone_II.management: Traditionally - explore if platysma violated; Modern - CTA-directed selective approach

Zone_III.boundaries: Angle of mandible to skull base
Zone_III.management: Imaging before operation; endovascular preferred for arterial injuries

modern.all_zones: CTA for stable patients - guides management
modern.selective_exploration: Based on CTA findings and clinical trajectory
modern.endovascular: Increasing role in Zone I and III injuries

hard_signs: Hemoptysis or air bubbling from wound

workup.CTA: First-line imaging for stable patients - all zones
workup.angiography: For intervention or when CTA inadequate
workup.surgical_exploration: Hard signs, unstable patient, or positive imaging

definition.@value: Classification of the neck into three horizontal zones (I, II, III) based on surgical accessibility, guiding the evaluation and management of penetrating neck trauma.

learning_objectives: Define the three zones of the neck and their boundaries
Identify key structures in each zone
Contrast traditional vs modern management algorithms
Apply zone-based approach to penetrating neck trauma
clinical_pearls: Zone II (cricoid to mandible angle) is ACCESSIBLE - can explore directly
Zone I (thoracic inlet) and Zone III (skull base) are DIFFICULT access - image first
Modern approach: CTA for ALL zones in STABLE patients
Hard signs = immediate OR regardless of zone
Endovascular options have expanded management of Zone I and III injuries
Platysma violation used to mandate exploration - now selective with CTA
